*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase products to sell in store

loans.name: So

texts.en: So P. is 59-year-old married woman and mother. She lives with other family members in her own small family home in Kompong Tom province. She owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandparent. So P. uses this farmland for growing rice crops, and she has been planting her crop in the dry-season rice field. Her husband assists her in the business. The couple is married and has four children, four of whom are single and still living under their care, while the other one is married. Two of their children are sewing workers in the garment factory. Because their farm is outside of a watering system, So P. would like a loan to buy a pumping machine for irrigation.

loans.use: To buy a pumping machine for irrigation

loans.name: Rubylyn

texts.en:
This is Rubylyn G..  She is 33 years old and is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Leonardo G. and is the mother of a college-aged child. At this time, Rubylyn is working hard to be able to continue supporting her child all the way through college.  This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Rubylyn, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance that parents can leave to their children.

Rubylyn operates a ready-to-wear clothing business. She mainly offers new clothing designs like casual wear and tropical wear. Seasonal demands for clothing like uniforms and such are available all year round. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more varieties of clothing designs to sell. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
 
Rubylyn dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes that her business will continue to grow and be successful. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more varieties of clothing designs to sell

loans.name: Socorro

texts.en:
This is Socorro L..  She is 40 years old and is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Abraham L. and is the mother of a college-aged child and four other children.  At this time, she is working hard to be able to continue supporting her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Socorro, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Socorro operates a ready-to-wear clothing business. She mainly offers new clothing designs like casual wear and tropical wear. Seasonal demands for clothing like uniforms and such are available all year round. Her regular customers are her neighbors and people in the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, Socorro is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more varieties of clothes designs to sell. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Socorro dreams to be able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes that her business will continue to grow and be successful. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more varieties clothes designs to sell

loans.name: Elbegsaihan

texts.en:
Elbegsaihan, 48, is married and lives with his wife and four children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. His two older daughters attend college while the younger two daughters attend a local secondary school.  His wife is unemployed and helps him with his business. 

Elbegsaihan became a carpenter in 1984 and opened his carpentry business in 2001 after his family moved to the city from the countryside.  He makes mostly woodcraft items and customized wood furniture, and sells his products at a local market. He supports his family's needs and pays his daughters' tuition fees with the income from this carpentry business.

Elbegsaihan is a modest and hardworking person who says, "our wish is to work hard and take care of our daughters' education".  Elbegsaihan is requesting a loan of 700,000 MNT to buy timber and materials for his carpentry business.

loans.use: To buy timber and carpentry materials

loans.name: Enkhzaya

texts.en: Enkhzaya, 44, is married and has two children. The eldest son, Chinzaya, 20, attends Art College to become a craftsman. They all live in their own small wooden house in Ulaanabaatar, the capital of Mongolia. For over twenty years, Enkhzaya worked in the “Urt Tsagaan” market as a cobbler. For the last six years she has been working for “HOM” LLC as a cobbler. She custom-makes products to her customers' order and design. Therefore, customers always remain satisfied and happy. She is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 MNT to buy furniture for the improvement of her house.

loans.use: to buy furniture for the improvement of her house.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
44-year-old Marilyn is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 5 children. Her eldest child is 17 years old while the youngest is only 7. Marilyn says she and her husband work extra hard, especially now that all their five children are going to school. Marilyn does her best to sustain her children's  education.

Marilyn is engaged in farming. She and her husband till their own land to plant and harvest rice crops. They sell their harvest to rice traders. 

Marilyn needs fertilizers and other farm supplies for her rice farm. She applied for a loan of 10000 PHP from CEVI for this purpose.  Marilyn wants to be a successful entrepreneur and is hopeful that this loan will help improve her business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and farm supplies

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
This is Martina B..  She is  49 years old and is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Alberto B., a tricycle driver. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to provide income to meet their everyday expenses.

Martina operates a variety store and an Internet cafe. In the Philippines, a variety store is a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood.  It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Php-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Arlene makes a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Her store and Internet shop is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are neighbors and people in the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help continue the operations of her businesses, Martina is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her store inventory, and to add a computer to her Internet shop. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Martina hopes to be able to expand soon, as she hopes to have her own house and lot in a prominent subdivision in a nice location. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy inventory for variety store, and computer for Internet shop

loans.name: Boldoo

texts.en:
Boldoo, 38, is married and lives with his wife and three children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on land they have owned for the past 10 years. His wife works as a distributor for a popular cosmetic company and his three children all attend a local school. 

Boldoo began a car repair business in 2000 and a welding business in 2008. He makes stoves for houses and gers on order. Now he has an inventory of 600,000 MNT that he uses to make the stoves. As a long time business owner, he has many regular customers. In the summer, he goes to the countryside and offers his service to the those people who live far from the city center.  

Boldoo is a hardworking and active person who says, "I am planning to have my own workshop in the future where I can operate my business consistently".  He is requesting a loan of 800,000 MNT to purchase more materials for his stove making business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for stove making business

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan K., 27, is the mother of a young child. She has been in the farming business for a long time in Kompong Tom province, Cambodia. To earn a living, Chan K. has cultivated a rice crop on her own farmland. With this loan, Chan K. will purchase a plot of farmland from a villager in order to expand and grow various kinds of crops. This will enable her family to accrue an extra profit to meet their daily expenses. Note: Chan K., her husband, and their lovely child appear in the photo.

loans.use: to purchase a plot of farmland in order to grow various kinds of crops.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
This is Vivian C..  She is 47 years old and is a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Edwin C., a fisherman, and is mother to their children. By the grace of God, Vivian has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send all of them all the way through college.  This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Vivian, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Vivian operates a cellular phone loading station while also managing their variety store and bed rental business (where she rents out bed space to travelers and students). In her phone loading business, Vivian buys electronic cellular phone loads in large amounts then retails it for how much the customer is paying. How much profit is generated depends on the networks' policy for their dealerships. She may buy Php 3000 worth of loads for Php 2500 and gain Php 500 in profit, depending on promos and quota set by the networks. 

Vivian is also readying a few pigs for slaughter and trading a variety of products to earn income.  For her variety store, she sells basic commodities such as groceries, rice, egs, cooking oik and the like, at  piece rate to her neighbors. 

To help continue the operations of her business, Vivian is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will invest some of the loan to buy electronic loads from different local networks. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Vivian hopes to be able to expand soon, and have more boarding houses to rent out to her customers. She also prays that she will be able to lead her whole family to her personal Lord and savior, the Lord Jesus Christ. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy mobile phone loads and add stocks for store

loans.name: Densenbal

texts.en:
Densenbal L. is  39 years old.  She is married and lives with her husband and four children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her two younger daughters attend a local secondary school. 

Densenbal used to operate a cafe, which she started in 2000. She ran the cafe for five years until she injured her legs. In 2005 she began making clothes from home. Her husband and two older daughters help her with this business. They make deels – Mongolian traditional long coats, vests, jackets, felt  slippers, as well as most kinds of custom handmade clothing. Densenbal  and her two daughters are responsible for the manufacturing and her husband does the delivery. 

Densenbal  is a sociable, hardworking person who says, "my wish is to help my daughters get their own jobs".  She is requesting a loan of 500,000 MNT to purchase more textiles and clothes for her handmade clothing business.

loans.use: To purchase more textiles and clothes

loans.name: May Joy

texts.en:
May Joy, 29 years old, lives in the town of Banga with her family. Her family owns a rice farm that she maintains with her husband. They plant and harvest rice. May Joy works hard to help provide for the increasing needs in their household. She does her best to keep her family happy and healthy.

May Joy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. May Joy is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to support her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
This is Criselda L., 40, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She manages her own household while helping her family. She works hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.

Criselda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages, piecemeal. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Arlene buys supplies at wholesale prices and sells by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 every day.

To help her continue business operations, she is requesting a Php 25,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Criselda hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to continue her maturation in her Lord Jesus Christ. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her inventory

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy D. is from the town of Banga. She is 42 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Nancy owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. She wants to be a successful businesswoman. 

Nancy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to buy additional fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is a widow from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She has 6 children to support. Rosemarie does her best to provide for her family's needs.

Rosemarie is engaged in farming. She primarily plants and harvests rice crops. She starts work early in the morning to ensure her rice crops are growing healthily. She keeps her farm free of weeds and pests. Rosemarie sells her harvest to rice traders.

Rosemarie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosemarie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to buy fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to support her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Yen N. is a 32-year-old married man who is blessed with four teenage children. He is currently a domestic construction worker, and works in the construction field at least eight hours per day. He receives an average profit of $5 from this job. He has a life partner in his wife, who is a local farmer. Recently, Yen N. says that he wants to buy a trailer to connect with his existing motorbike in order to transport palm fruits to the mobile place for selling. That is the reason Yen N. is applying for a $600 loan from Kiva’s partner HKL. This loan will provide Yen N. and his family with additional income.

loans.use: to buy a trailer for his motorbike in order to transport palm fruits for selling.

loans.name: Tumenjarga

texts.en:
Tumenjargal, 45, is married and lives with her husband and two children in the Suhbaatar district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband works as a driver for a company and her younger son attends a local secondary school. They have a decent standard of living. 

Tumenjargal operates a grocery trading business. Tumenjargal began selling meat products, such as smoked sausage and smoked pork, vegetables and other products at a stall in the local market in 2008. She wants to expand her business and operate additional stalls in the future. She is a hardworking and polite person who says, " I like my business and want to expand it in the future." She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome L. is from the town of Banga. She is 52 years old, married and has 9 children. Salome owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. She hopes that her harvest will increase.

Salome joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Salome is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. This will be her second loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to support her family.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim M. is a married man who currently resides in the middle of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. He is a soldier who works in his village. He started his job more than a year ago. Sim M. is blessed with one young child who is not yet enrolled in school. His wife works as a sewing worker and also spends time at home taking care of the child and doing housework. The family’s living conditions are currently poor, because their house is old and a few parts are broken down. To solve the problem, Sim M. requested a loan to hire a few construction workers to mend his broken house.

loans.use: to hire a few construction workers to mend his broken house.

loans.name: Mary Isabel

texts.es:
La Sra. Mary Isabel, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Solidarias II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martin, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 40 años y es madre de 01 hijo, que aun dependen de ella. 

Lleva mucho tiempo  dedicándose a la Venta de Joyas, bañadas en oro y plata.  Se inicio con un capital de 500 Nuevos Soles y poco a poco, fue comprando e implementando más su negocio. Gracias al Movimiento Manuela Ramos y a su empeño de salir adelante, ya es muy conocida por sus clientes, se encuentra ubicada en su misma, pero por las tardes ella visita a sus amistades para ofrecer sus productos. Se dedica también a la venta de cosméticos de la línea Esika, nos cuenta que sus ventas y pedidos diarios, son muy buenos. En la actualidad continua con los dos negocios y le va muy bien.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,200.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará Joyas, bañadas en oro y plata como: aretes, collares, pulseras, anillos, en diferentes modelos y dibujos. También invertirá comprando cosméticos, para aumentar su stock como: Colonias, perfumes, talcos, desodorantes y cremas, tanto para damas y caballeros. Es una mujer con muchas ganas de salir adelante para el bienestar de su familia y de ella misma. 

Mary Isabel, manifiesta su más gentil agradecimiento al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer y apoyar a otras mujeres que también quieren salir adelante.
texts.en: Mary Isabel belongs to the "Las Solidarias II" community bank in the district of Tarapoto, province and department of San Martin. She's 40 years old, married and has one son, who is still a dependent. For a long time she has made a living selling jewelery coated in gold and silver. She started with 500 Nuevos Soles of capital and little by little she started buying items and better implementing her business. Thanks to Kiva partner Movimiento Manuela Ramos and Mary Isabel's desire to make headway, she is now well known among her customers. She runs her business out of her home, but in the afternoons she visits friends to offer her products. She also makes a living selling Esika-brand cosmetics and tells us that her daily sales and orders are very good. Currently she is continuing on with both businesses and it is going very well. With this loan of 1,200 Nuevos Soles, she plans to purchase more gold and silver jewelry such as earrings, necklaces, bracelets and rings in different models and designs. She will also invest in the purchase of cosmetics for men and women, such as colognes, perfumes, powders, deodorants and creams, to increase her stock. Mary Isabel is a woman with a strong desire to make headway for her family's well-being and her own. She expresses her greatest appreciation to Movimiento Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow as a businesswoman and a woman, and supporting other women who also want to make headway.

loans.use: Purchase gold and silver jewelry, and cosmetics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase summer clothing, fragrances, shampoos, lotions, hair gels, hair creams, and other personal care products

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.es: Maria Teresa M. D. T. 44 años D. edad, resiD. en Mejicanos, en el departamento D. San Salvador, en donD. vive junto a su esposo y tres hijos, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Ella se dedica a comercializar ropa para mujeres y niños, la cual comercializa en el mercado D. San Miguelito ubicado en San Salvador, negocio gracias al cual cuenta con una entrada economica que le ayuda a la economia D. su hogar. Ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. ropa, en diferentes tallas y colores, esto lo hace con el deseo D. poder obtener mayor cantidad D. clientes y así percibir más ganancias, lo cual es muy importante para María ya que el sueldo D. su esposo es bastante bajo para solventar todos los gastos del hogar, razón por la cual María se esfuerza mucho por mejorar su negocio.
texts.en: Maria is 44 years old and lives in Mejicanos, department of San Salvador, with her husband and three children, who are in school. Maria makes a living selling clothes for women and children in the San Miguelito market in San Salvador. The business has provided her with income to help the household finances. Maria is requesting the loan so that she can purchase larger quantities of clothing in different styles and colors, out of the desire to attract more customers and in turn more profits. That is very important to Maria because her husband's salary isn't enough to cover all the household expenses, which is why Maria works very hard to improve her business.

loans.use: Purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es: Manuel   G. C. de 48 años de edad, reside en el departamento de San Salvador en donde vive junto a su esposa y dos hijos los cuales dependen de él.  Manuel comercializa productos de primera necesidad como: pan, jugos, leche, huevos y otros más. Desde hace tres años que  posee este tipo de negocio el cual nació por la necesidad de poder contar con una fuente de ingresos fijos, la cual le permitiera contar con todo lo necesario para vivir de una manera aceptable. Manuel solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para invertir en su negocio, comprando productos como: embutidos, sodas, medicinas y otros productos más los cuales son de mucha  necesidad y que hasta ahora no poseía, razón por la cual perdía algunas ventas. Para él es de mucha importancia poder mejorar su negocio, ya que de esta manera podrá tener una vida mejor.
texts.en: Manuel is 48 years old and lives in the department of San Salvador with his wife and two children, who are dependent on him. Manuel sells products of primary need such as bread, juices, milk, eggs and many others. For the past three years he has had this business, which started out of the necessity to have a fixed source of income, and it has allowed him to have everything he needs to live in an acceptable way. Manuel is requesting the loan so he can invest in his business by purchasing products like sausages, sodas, medicines and other products of high necessity that until now he has not possessed, which has cost him some sales. It is very important to Manuel to be able to improve his business since in that way he will be able to have a better life.

loans.use: Purchase primary-need items

loans.name: Marcos Antonio

texts.es: Marcos Antonio E. R. de 30 años de edad, es un hombre muy responsable y trabajador, el cual vive junto a su esposa y dos hijos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar, y con quienes reside en San Jacinto en el departamento de San Salvador. Con mucho esfuerzo hace 7 años que Marcos logro comprar un bus, el cual en la actualidad le permite contar con una fuente de ingresos para su familia. Él se dedica a hacer viajes para personas que se dirijen a la iglesia Elim, una de las iglesias más grandes del país, los viajes los realiza  todos los días de la semana, contando con clientes fijos. Marcos solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar llantas nuevas, y así mismo para contar con el dinero necesario para hacerle todas las revisiones y arreglos necesarios, de manera que pueda contar con un bus en mejores condiciones, el cual le permita seguir ganando dinero y así mismo pueda brindar seguridad a sus clientes.
texts.en: Marcos is 30 years old and a very responsible and hard-working man. He lives in San Jacinto, department of San Salvador, with his wife and two young children, who are in school. Seven years ago with a lot of hard work Marcos was able to purchase a bus, which today provides his family with a source of income. He makes a living transporting people to Elim church, one of the biggest churches in the country. He makes the trip every day of the week with a fixed clientele. Marcos is requesting the loan so he can purchase new tires and have the money to make all the necessary improvements and repairs so his bus will be in better condition. This will allow him to keep making money and providing a safe service to his customers.

loans.use: Make improvements and repairs to his bus

location.town: San Jacinto , departamento de San Salvador

loans.name: Maria Berfalia

texts.es: Maria Berfalia L. C. de 43 años de edad, reside en el municipio de ilopango, en donde vive junto a su esposa y dos hijos, los cuales son estudiantes. María posee una tortillería, la cual esta ubicada en su propia casa, desde hace un tiempo atrás que ella se dedica a este oficio, debido a que es madre muy responsable a la cual le interesa aportar económicamente a su hogar. Es por esta razón que María debe trabajar muy duro por seguir adelante tratando de crecer en su negocio de tortillas. María solicitó un préstamo a Integral con la esperanza de poder mejorar las condiciones de su negocio, ya que por medio de este ella comprará mayor cantidad de maíz, el cual al comprarlo por mayor lo obtiene a precios más bajos. Esto será de mucho beneficio para ella ya que le permitirá atender mayor demanda, lo cual le brindará mayores ganancias. Esto llena de muchas esperanzas a María ya que contará con el dinero necesario para brindarle todos lo necesario a sus hijos.
texts.en: Maria Berfalia Leon C. is 43 years old and resides in the municipality of Ilopango where she lives with her spouse and 2 children; they are students.  Maria has a tortilla making business that she has been running out of her home for some time now.  She is a responsible mother who likes to contribue economically to the household.  This is why Maria must work really hard to get ahead and continue to grow her business of making tortillas.  Maria has solicited a loan from Integral with the hope of improving her working conditions and purchasing corn in bulk which allows her to purchase it at a lower price.  This will be very beneficial to her because it will allow her to meet a greater demand and bring in more earnings.  This fills Maria with a lot of hope since she counts on the money to offer her kids all the necessary things.

loans.use: Purchase corn to produce more tortillas

loans.name: Thoeurn

texts.en: Thoeurn T. is a 24-year-old man from Kompong Chame province, married to Ly Soophat, also 24.  The couple also lives with two school-aged children. Both T. and Soophat earn a living by growing rice on their own farmland, which comes from their grandparent. They currently generate an income of approximately $4.50 per day from their business. Thoeurn T. is taking out this loan to purchase a piece of land in a good location for building a house. This loan will provide him with an additional new asset.

loans.use: to purchase a piece of land in a good location for building a house.

loans.name: Mirna Cecilia

texts.es: Mirna Cecilia P. D. F. es una madre D. familia muy responsable y trabajadora, la cual se dedica por completo a su familia, ella vive junto a sus tres hijos, en el municipio D. San Martín, mismo lugar en el cual posee sun egocio, su esposo resiD. en Los Estados Unidos gracias a lo que Mirna recibe remesas. Ella trabaja elaborando pupusas, las cuales son un platillo típico D. este país, por lo que esta venta en un negocio bastante estable. Mirna solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. maís, arroz, frijoles, queso y chicharrón, D. manera que pueda contar con mayor cantidad D. materia prima para elaborar las pupusas. Todo esto lo hace con el enorme deseo D. podar mejorar su estabilidad familiar y D. esta forma vivir mejor junto a su familia.
texts.en: Mirna Cecilia P. D. F. is a responsible mother, hard-working, and dedicates herself to her family.  She lives with her 3 children in the San Martin municipality, same place as her business.  Her husband lives in the United States and thankfully sends Mirna remittances.  She works making pupusas, which is a typicall dish in this country and provides for a stable business.  Mirna requested a loan in order to purchase greater quantities of corn, rice, beans, cheese, and pork rinds; this way she has a larger quantity of raw materials to make the pupusas.  She does all of this with an enormous wish of improving her family's stability and living better off alongsiD. her family.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials to make pupusas (corn based dish typically with some sort of stuffing)

loans.name: Muhoi

texts.en:
Muhoi K. has been practicing mixed farming for twelve years now in Murang'a town, central Kenya. He sells his tea through Kenya Tea Development Authority and milk to the local market. He depends primarily on the income from his farm to cater for the basic needs of his family.

Muhoi is 44 years old and married with 3 children, who all attend school.

Muhoi has requested a loan of 55,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo, for poultry farming. This loan will allow him to buy layers and chicken feed, which will enable him to expand his poultry farming. The extra income from the the sale of eggs will help improve his family's livelihood. In the future, he would like to expand his poultry farm and raise broilers as well. He says that diseases and the high cost of chicken feeds against low prices of eggs have been his major challenges.

loans.use: poultry farming.

loans.name: Gloria Esperanza

texts.es: Gloria Esperanza V., reside en Bosques de San Antonio, ubicado en la cabecera departamental de Santa Ana, lugar en el cual vive sola, ya que su único hijo es mayor de edad y vive en casa propia, a pesar de esto le brinda una pequeña ayuda a su madre. Gloria se dedica a la venta de productos varios, entre ellos, jugos, galletas, tostadas de yuca y plátano, sodas, entre otras más. Gloria es muy trabajadora y dedicada a su trabajo, ya que cuenta con el enorme deseo de poder mejorar su negocio aún más y de esta forma percibir mayores ganancias. Es por esto que solicita un préstamo a Integral, pormedio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para invertir comprando mayor cantidad de productos que ya posee y así mismo incluir nuevos. Su negocio es muy estable, ya que se encuentra a la salida de una escuela por lo que posee clientes fijos y ventas diarias.
texts.en:
Gloria Esperanza V. resides in Bosques de San Antonio, which is located in the departmental capital of Santa Ana. She lives alone since her only child is grown and lives in his own home despite having to provide his mother with a little bit of support. Gloria sells various products including juices, cookies, plantain and cassava chips, sodas, and other items. She is a hard worker who is dedicated to her job. Gloria has tremendous desire to improve her business so that she can generate better earnings.

For this reason she is requesting a loan from Apoyo Integral in order to have the money needed to invest in the purchase of a large quantity of products, which includes new items. Her business is very stable since it is located outside of a school where she has established customers and can make daily sales.

loans.use: Purchase candies to sell

location.town: Bosques de San Antonio, departamento de Santa Ana

loans.name: María Del Carmen

texts.es: María Del Carmen R. D. A. D. 44 años D. edad, resiD. en San Juan Opico, ubicado en el departamento D. La Libertad. Ella vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como comerciante D. granos básicos, y así mismo vive con dos hijos menores D. edad. María posee una pequeña venta D. juguetes, cosméticos, grano básicos y articulos para el hogar, los cuales comercializa en su casa D. habitación, este negocios es muy necesario para su familia, por lo que desea ampliarlo aún más. María solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. juguetes, cosméticos en mayor variedad y así mismo articulos para el hogar. D. esta forma María espera mejorar en gran manera sus ganancias y D. esta forma vivir mejor junto a su familia.
texts.en:
María Del Carmen R. D. A. is 44 years old and resides in San Juan Opico, which is located in the Department of La Libertad. She lives with her husband, who works as a grain merchant, and their two young children. María has a small store in her home where she sells toys, cosmetics, basic grains, and household products. This business is very important to her family, so she wants to expand it even more.

María is requesting a loan that she can buy a large quantity of toys, a wiD. variety of cosmetics, and household goods. In this manner, María hopes to improve her earnings so that she and her family can live better.

loans.use: Purchase toys, cosmetics, and household goods to sell

location.town: San Juan Opico, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Pon

texts.en: The woman in the photo is Pon S., age 41, who lives in the Province of Kompong Tom, Cambodia, where she earns a living raising pigs. She is married with three children, all of whom are single. Since 2000, she has run this business and it has provided her with income to attain her standard of living. Beside this work, she has also been planting the rice crop that is her annual business. Her husband works in this farming business. Pon S. is looking for a loan as capital to support her farming business. She will use the loan to buy gasoline and many sacks of fertilizers to help her rice crop grow well.

loans.use: to purchase gasoline and many sacks of fertilizer for her rice crop.

loans.name: Evelyn Elizabeth

texts.es: Evelyn Elizabeth F. C. de 36 años de edad, reside en San Marcos, ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador, capital del país. Ella es madre soltera de tres hijos los cuales se dedican a estudiar. posee una tienda de abarrotes, en los cuales comercializa productos de primera necesidad como pastas, pan, huevos y otros más los cuales son fundamentales dentro de un hogar. Ella cuenta con 5 años de poseer el negocio, el cual le ha permitido ir mejorando su economía familiar, la cual en muchas ocasiones es bastante mala, sobre todo porque muchas veces ella no cuenta con todos los productos que las personas buscan lo cual le baja en gran manera sus ganancias. Es por esta razón que Evelyn solicita un préstamo a integral, con el fin de poder contar con el dinero necesario para poder surtir su negocio con esos productos tan necesarios que no posee, así mismo con el deseo de poder aumentar la cantidad de los que ya posee. Evelyn desea mejorar su negocio, sobre todo porque ella es madre soltera, y debe velar por sus hijos cada día, esto a pesar que uno de los hijos mayores trabaja, esto no da abasto con los gastos del hogar, razón Por la cual  posee la esperanza de poder mejorar su situación gracias a este préstamo.
texts.en:
Evelyn Elizabeth F. C. is 36 years old and resides in San Marcos in the Department of San Salvador, the national capital. She is a single mother of three children who are in school. Evelyn has a grocery store where she sells basic necessities such as pasta, bread, eggs, and other basic items used in the home. She has managed her business for five years, which enabled her to improve her family’s finances. There have been several occasions when her financial situation was very bad because she did not carry all the products that people were looking for, which lowered her profits significantly.

For this reason, Evelyn is requesting a loan from Apoyo Integral so that she can have the necessary funds to supply her business with the necessary products that she does not have in stock. She wants to improve her business, primarily because she is a single mother, so that she can provide for her children each day. Despite the fact that one of her older children is working, she is not able to cope with the household expenses. This is why she hopes this loan will improve her situation.

loans.use: Purchase basic necessities

location.town: San Marcos, departamento de San Salvador

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es: Mercedes B. D. Q. resiD. en la urbanización monte blanco D.  D. Soyapango en el departamento D. San Salvador. Con  40 años D. edad, resiD. junto a su esposo y dos hijos pequeños. Para poder salir adelante, ella inició a las afueras D. su casa una pequeña venta D. frutas y verduras, la cual ha ido creciendo con mucho esfuerzo. Mercedes solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda mejorar aún más su negocio comprando mayor cantidad D. frutas D. estación y D. verduras. La mayor ilusión D. Mercedes es el D. salir adelante y D. esta forma vivir mejor junto a su familia, la cual la necesita en gran manera.
texts.en:
Mercedes B. D. Q. resides in the urban neighborhood of Monte Blanco in Soyapango, Department of San Salvador. She is 40 years old and lives with her husband and two young children. In order to get ahead, Mercedes opened a small fruit and vegetable stand outsiD. of her home. Her business has grown through much effort.

Mercedes is requesting a loan so that she can improve her business by purchasing a large quantity of seasonal fruits and vegetables. Her greatest wish is to move forward and be able to have a better life with her family, something she truly needs.

loans.use: Purchase seasonal fruits & vegetables

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne, 60, is married with 2 children who are now adults. She has been farming in the town of Murang'a in central Kenya for ten years. She employs two farmhands and sells her products to the local market. 

Anne has requested a loan of 60,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo for poultry farming. She says that the proceeds from her farm will increase her income and ensure that she is financially independent. Her major challenge has been the high cost of animal feed.

loans.use: poultry farming

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is a married woman who lives in Bantayan, Cebu. She operates 2 businesses: hog raising and buying & selling dried fish. Her husband, Raul, who is 62 years old, works as a laborer. They have 10 children aged between 15 and 37 years old. 

Marina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 17 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, lifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 18th loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,500. She intends to use this to buy medicines and vaccines for pigs so that she can continue to save up for future house repairs and the expansion of her business. Marina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 	

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase medicines and vaccines for her pigs

loans.name: Faith Wanjiku

texts.en:
Faith Wanjiku D. is 39 years old, single and the mother of three children. She lives with her family in Kipsongo, on the outskirts of Kitale. She has operated a dry cleaning (laundry) shop in the same area for one year and earns a monthly income of KES 10,000.

This will be Faith's first loan from KADET LTD. She plans to use it to buy a bigger dry cleaning machine so that she can serve her customers better and faster. In the future, she wants to educate her children to the highest level and to own the best dry cleaning place in Kitale.

loans.use: to buy a dry cleaning machine

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a married woman who lives in Danao City, Cebu. She operates 2 business ventures: a general store and a food vending (bananaque) business. Her husband, Marcelo, who is 52 years old, works as a carpenter and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have seven children aged between 18 and 23 years old. 

Flora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Flora has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,600, lifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 5th loan, she is borrowing PHP 15,000. She intends to use this to buy more products to sell so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and house repairs. Flora is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase additional product items to sell

loans.name: Mutui Ole  Tako

texts.en:
Mutui Ole Tako L. is 36 years old, married and the father of three school-going children. Mutui has been farming on his own piece of land for the last four years.

Mutui learned about KADET LTD from a colleague who is already a KADET registered client. This will be his second loan, which he plans to use to prepare the land and to buy farm supplies. The farm is located along the main road, which makes it easy for him to get customers for his maize. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, Mutui will reinvest in the farm to increase his maize production. In the future, he wants to venture into commercial farming.

loans.use: to prepare the land and to buy farm supplies

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle is a married woman who lives in Compostela, Cebu. She operates 2 business ventures:  abaca weaving and a general store. Her husband, Ronelo, who is 48 years old, works as a farmer and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 4 children aged between 16 and 25.

Annabelle joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Annabelle has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, lifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 11th loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her abaca weaving business. In that way she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and home repairs. Annabelle is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund the operation of her business

loans.name: Kandai

texts.en: Kandai O. K. is 42 years old, married and the father of eight children. Kandai has been operating a retail shop in Narok town for 11 years and earns a good income. He learned about KADET LTD from KADET staff during their marketing campaign. This will be his second loan and he plans to use it to buy more stock for the shop, such as rice, sugar, cooking fat, etc. The business is doing well due to its strategic location at the center of the area. Kandai will reinvest in the business with the anticipated profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan. In the future, he hopes to own a wholesale shop.

loans.use: to buy more stock

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
50-year-old Susan is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 4 children. Susan owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also runs a sari-sari (variety) store.

Susan joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Susan is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to buy farm inputs such as fertilizers. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to support her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs such as fertilizers

loans.name: Erlita

texts.en:
Erlita is a married woman who lives in Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She operates a general store. Her husband, Anacleto, who is 43 years old, works as a farmer. They have 4 children aged between 12 and 25 years old. 

Erlita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Erlita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 25,000, lifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 3rd loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock. In this way she can continue to save up for the future and for her children’s education. Erlita is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: to purchase more stock

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman with four children, two of whom attend school while two are still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are clothing, rent and food for the family.

She has operated a fish selling business for the past three years. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. Judith faces the major challenge of competition from other fish sellers in the market. She hopes to own a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of fish for sale and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of fish for sale and cooking oil.

loans.name: Virginita

texts.en:
Virginita, 56 years old, is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 7 children. Virginita owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice and corn for sale. Virginita works hard to improve her business and to earn more for her family.

Virginita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Virginita has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Benita's Group

texts.en:
Benita P. is from the village of Talaytay, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Benita is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Benita P. Group.

Benita is married and has 3 school-aged children. She owns & operates a general store where she sells a variety of products. She has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Benita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand the product offering. This will be her 7th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand the product offering

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stock of handbags and vitenges

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is 43 years old.  She is married and supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: a fishing/fish vending business and a pig fattening business. She lives in Basay, Negros Oriental. 

Gemma has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8000. 

Gemma is borrowing PHP 28000 so that she can fund her business operations. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 20000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step on her journey toward economic freedom. Gemma aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund business operations

loans.name: Nget

texts.en:
Cultivating rice is part of 47-year-old Nget N.’s daily routine. She and her husband always plant their rice crops following the dry and rainy seasons. Nget N. also makes bamboo baskets for the market. She is the mother of five unmarried children, three of whom are employed in different jobs.

Nget N.'s house is in the repair process but it is not yet finished because she doesn't have enough savings to continue. To deal with this problem, Nget N. is asking for a loan to buy wood to finish repairing her house. She hopes to use the rest of the loan to buy rice for the family to eat.

loans.use: to buy wood to finish repairing her house

loans.name: Sheikha

texts.en:
Sheikha is a single woman who owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, clothing and transportation. 

She has been operating a tailoring business for the past five years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Sheikha faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to purchase more materials for tailoring in the future.

With the Kshs 80,000 loan, she wants to purchase bundles of cloth materials for her tailoring business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase cloth materials for tailoring business

loans.name: Mburu

texts.en: Mburu is 73 years old.  He is widowed and have four children.  For more than twenty years, he has been operating a retail shop.  Through Faulu Kenya, he has improved his business and bought a piece of land.  He has also seen his children through school.   He hopes to fully establish his business and leave it to his family to continue running it in the future.  Mburu has requested a loan for 70, 000 Kes to buy sugar, rice, beans, wheat flour, cooking fat and salt.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, beans, wheat flour, cooking fat and salt

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a married woman who lives in Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures: a general store and a hog raising business.  Her husband Felix helps her run the businesses.  They have 6 children who are between 36 and 41 years old.  All of them now  have their own family. 

Gloria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gloria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 6 cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 15000, which she intends to use as working capital for her businesses so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Gloria is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To use as working capital for businesses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay school fees

loans.name: Gachmaa

texts.en:
Gachmaa is a 44 year-old widow.  She lives with her two children in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. The family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, inside a relative's fence. Her daughter goes to university and her son attends the local elementary school. Since 2002, Gachmaa has operated a food-making business, and she sells her products in her local market. Because she has operated her business for almost 8 years, she has her own loyal customers. 

Gachmaa makes about 10,000-15,000 MNT a day, but she spends about 80% of a day's income to buy material to prepare food to sell on the following day.  Gachmaa is a modest, friendly woman who says "I want to give a good education to my two children." She is requesting a loan of 100,000 MNT to buy meat and flour for her food-making business.

loans.use: To buy meat and flour

loans.name: Tunjung Wiguna Group

texts.en:
Ni Ketut W., a 42-year-old woman living in Pangkung Liplip Kaliakah Village, is the head of the group called "Tunjung Wiguna", They have obtained a loan of Rp. 15,000,000 and the group has a total of 10 people, so that each person will obtain a loan of Rp. 1.5 million. Ni Ketut W. raises pigs from birth up to the age of three months; they are then ready for sale so that within a 6-month period she may sell two times. 

Ni Ketut W. can maintain 3 to 4 head of pigs. From the sale of livestock she can obtain an average of Rp.600.000 per six months. With these earnings she can help cover the family living expenses. The members of the group hope that in future this cooperation can continue to run smoothly.

loans.use: Buy more pigs

loans.name: Wiguna Merta Group

texts.en:
Ni Nengah R., 42 years old, lives in Pangkung Liplip Kaliakah Village and is the head of the group "Wiguna Merta", which has obtained a loan for second period of Rp. 15,000,000. The group has a total of 10 people, so that each person will obtain a loan of Rp. 1.5 million. 

Ni Nengah R. raises pigs from piglets up to the age of three months. They can then be ready for sale so that within six months, she may sell two times. Ni Nengah R. can maintain 3 to 4 head of pigs. From the sale of livestock she can obtain an average income of Rp.600.000 per six  months. From this income she is able to help cover the family living expenses. The members of the group hope that in future this cooperation can continue to run smoothly.

loans.use: Buy more pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy maize.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma C. is from the town of Banga. She is 37 years old and married, with 3 children aged 9, 6 and 1. To make a living, Wilma plants and harvests rice for sale. One of Wilma's dreams is to be a successful entrepreneur.

Wilma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, to be used to purchase fertilizer and pay for services. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, the organization has numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pay for services

loans.name: Adelia

texts.en:
Adelia is a married woman who lives in Talisay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  selling balut (fertilized duck eggs) and selling fish. Her husband Marcelo, who is 57 years old, works as a vendor to earn a living, and also helps Adelia with her business activities. They have four children between 19 and 32 years old. 

Adelia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 4 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Adelia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,800, improving the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 5th loan, she is borrowing PHP 12,000, which she intends to use to buy stocks of balut so that she can continue to save up for future improvements in her businesses. Adelia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through its programs, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy additional balut (fertilized duck eggs)

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida, 46 years old, is a married woman from the town of Surallah. She has 2 children aged 18 and 13. To make a living, Aida owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Aida also helps her husband maintain their rice farm.

Aida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Aida is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs and pig feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and pig feed

loans.name: Anecito

texts.en:
Anecito E. is from the town of Surallah. He is 46 years old. Anecito is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Anecito owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Anecito does his best to build his business.

Anecito joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anecito is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Anecito from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en: Kennedy is a married man with three children.  He runs the Faith and Hope Academy.  He opened the school three years ago and has employed four people.  He is also a church pastor.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has managed to meet his family’s needs.  This is becuase he previously took out a loan from Faulu Kenya which he used to boost his business.  He hopes to expand his school into a primary school in the future.  With 50, 000 Kes, he will buy text books and furniture.

loans.use: To buy text books and furniture

loans.name: 01 Dong Son Group

texts.en:
Vui L. T. (7) is a 41 year-old woman living in the town of Thanh Hoa.  Vui is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 01 Dong Son (10.03.01 Dong Son).

Vui is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To making a living, Vui owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling peanuts in the local community.  Vui has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1.500.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, Vui joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Vui has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4.248.000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5.787.900 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the 8th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Vui plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand the business.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  P. T. Hoa (6) is a 35 year-old woman who is requesting a 5787900 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business.

2.  L. T. Mien (5) is a 73 year-old woman who is requesting a 5787900 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

3.  D. T. Tu (16) is a 33 year-old woman who is requesting a 4248000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

4.  H. T. Ngan (13) is a 31 year-old woman who is requesting a 3079800 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Eleanor

texts.en:
54-year-old Eleanor lives in the town of Surallah with her family. She is engaged in rice farming, hog-raising and retail selling. She and her husband maintain a rice farm. They sell their harvest to rice traders. She also raises pigs in their backyard and runs a small sari-sari store. Eleanor does all these activities to provide the increasing needs in their household.

Eleanor joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eleanor has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Eleanor is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and pig feed. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pig feed

loans.name: Mutojo Tukwatanise Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
K. James is the leader of Mutojo Tukwatanise group in Kihihi. He is 36 years old and married with 4 children. Two of his children are in school. He also takes care of other dependents. 

James has a business of selling second hand clothes from Katete Trading centre and he describes his customers as good clients. He is able to make 100,000 UGX as weekly profits and he needs a loan to be able to buy more clothes for resale. He has been in this kind of business for 5 years after investing money from his tailoring workshop.
