He is a very hard working man and one of his dreams is to be able to improve his tailoring workshop and educate his children.

loans.use: Buying more second hand clothes for resale.

loans.name: Asri Lestari Group

texts.en: After repaying their first loan correctly, "Asri Lestari" group has received a second loan. Ni Nyoman L. M. plans to use her share of this loan to buy four piglets. As for the cost of feed, she will bear that expense herself. She was satisfied with the results she got from the first period so she decided to expand her business. For the second period, she hopes that her business will do well, there will be no disease, and hog prices will be high when she sells her pigs.

loans.use: Buy more pigs

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janette G. is from the town of Surallah. She is 41 years old. Janette is married and has 2 children aged 21 and 14. To make a living, Janette owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Janette wants a successful business that's why she is working hard to achieve her dreams.

Janette joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janette is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer, chemicals and other farm supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Janette from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, chemicals and other farm supplies

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice N. G. is a married lady with three children whom she hopes to give good education to the university level. Her business is located at Changamwe Magongo estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites not forgetting the Indian ocean white beaches. 

She does photocopying and printing services to the local people. She also sells stationery which does very well as the business is situated near a primary school. She has been doing this business for the last three years now. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Beatrice is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy exercise books, pens and printing paper to grow her business. She hopes to open a bookshop in future. She describes herself as a very patient and aggressive business woman.

loans.use: To buy exercise books, pens and printing paper

loans.name: Kang

texts.en: Kang C. has been farming for years in Kompong Chhnang. She plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates an income of $2.50 per day. Her husband earns a living selling firewood and cows. He always purchases cows from other farmers in and around his village and resells them for profit. In order to stimulate her husband’s business, Kang C. has decided to ask for a loan to buy many cows at reasonable prices for future sales.

loans.use: to buy many cows at reasonable prices

loans.name: Naranbaatar

texts.en:
Naranbaatar is 30 years old, lives with his parents in Ger, which is a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent in Ulaanbaatar the Mongolian capital city. His parents are retired. 
He has been operating taxi service in city for the last three years and has gained a lot of experience. Naranbaatar has one younger brother who is running taxi business as well, by using Naranbaatar’s other car. In the future he wants to sell his old car to get a newer one in better condition.  He is a very responsible and optimistic person and he started building a house on his parents plot of land. He is asking for a loan to increase his working capital to purchase some spare parts for his two cars which are used for his taxi business.

loans.use: loan to increasing his working capital.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a vegetable selling business for the past ten years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Judith faces a major challenge of seasonality. During dry hot season the availability of vegetables for sale is lower and demand is higher hence not meeting customers demand. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of vegetables for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Silas

texts.en:
Silas W. K. is a married man. His wife is a business woman and they have seven children aged between twenty one years old and three years old. His business is located at a very busy market known as Kongowea in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites not forgetting the Indian ocean white beaches. 

He sells fruits mainly water melons to the local people. He has been a fruit vendor for the last ten years. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints and dishonest customers who purchase on credit and fail to honor their request. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to increase the stock of water melons to grow his business and meet the demands of his customers. He hopes to o be able to supply fruits in wholesale to all major hotels in Mombasa in the future. He describes himself as honest, trustworthy and reliable.

loans.use: Water melons

loans.name: Lovelyn

texts.en:
Lovelyn S. is from the town of Surallah. She is 23 years old. Lovelyn is married and has 2 children aged 4 and 2. To make a living, Lovelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lovelyn works hard to provide for her family.

Lovelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lovelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lovelyn is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: William

texts.en: William, a father of ten, runs Bodaboda (motorbike) transport business.  He started the business in 2008.  He joined Jamhuri Bodaboda group whose members run bodaboda business.  In the group, he saves his money, share business ideas and he is able to get a loan easily from Faulu Kenya because the members guarantee each other loans.  He has requested for 10, 000 Kes through the group.  He will use the loan to buy a motorcycle  for transport business.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson N. C. is thirty one years old, married and has two children aged eight years old and five years old. His business is located at a very busy market known as Likoni in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites not forgetting the Indian ocean white beaches. 

He owns a general store in which he sells such items as cooking fat, beverages, cereals and other items to the local people. He has been in this business for the last ten years now and has managed to provide employment to three people. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has are financial constraints and dishonest customers who purchase on credit and fail to honor their request. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to increase the stock of general items to grow his business and meet the demands of his customers. He hopes to be a wholesaler in future. He describes himself as a very creative man.

loans.use: To buy flour, cooking fat, beverages, cereals etc

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 29 years old, married and a father of two.  He has a quarry business with which he earns a living.  He has been running the business for five years and has employed three people.  He joined Faulu Kenya so that he would save his money and access loan easily.  Hence, he has managed to improve his business.  He hopes to continue growing his business to get a better income. 

 He has requested for 20, 000 Kes to buy a water pump for the operation in the quarry and to get income to pay his addition employees.

loans.use: To buy a water pump for the operation in the quarry and to pay his additional employees.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda is a married woman who lives in Cadiz, Negros Occidental.  She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  a sari-sari (general) tore and a hog raising businesses.  Her husband Thanny, who is 58 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have 3 children who are 22 to 28 years old.

 Imelda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 5 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Imelda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 6th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000 which she intends to use as more funds in her business operations so that she could continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Imelda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF:  
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Funds for her business operations

loans.name: Melindy

texts.en:
47-year-old Melindy lives in the town of Surallah with her family. She is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Melindy owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Melindy also helps her husband maintain their rice farm. She also helps in selling their harvest to the community.

Melindy joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melindy has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Melindy is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed and fertilizer. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase feed and fertilizer

loans.name: Camlita

texts.en:
Camlita is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a food vending business for the past seven years, her potential customers are neighbours and passerby. In addition she has real estate houses which contributes to her other source of income. She hopes to expand and build a permanent stall in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his stock of television sets

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida, 34 years old, is a married woman from the town of Surallah. Nida is a rice farmer and hog-grower. She cultivates her land for planting and harvesting rice farm. She rents a stall at the market to sell her harvest. Nida also raises pigs in her backyard. The pigs she grows are for fattening and sale. Nida works hard to be able to sustain her family.

Nida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Nida is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to buy piglets, feed and fertilizer. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy piglets, feed and fertilizer

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie C. is from the town of Surallah. She is 46 years old. Tessie is married and has 6 children. To make a living, Tessie owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Tessie wishes for her children to be successful someday.

Tessie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Tukoleinho Women's Group-Jinja

texts.en:
Syliva N. is 28 years old and the happily married mother of six. For the past six years, she has been a poultry farmer in Kabulenga-Jinja. Her business generates a weekly income of 100,000 UGX. Syliva began this business with savings from her small food sales business. She is a stickler for hard work and is looking to expand her business horizons when she gets this loan. 

Syliva belongs to the Tukoleinho Women’s group-Jinja. With this loan, she will purchase more chicks to resell once they mature.

loans.use: to purchase chicks

loans.name: Vuffie

texts.en:
Vuffie is 35 years old and married with three children who are two, four and 14. She lives in the town of Surallah, South Cotabato with her family. Vuffie is described as friendly by her neighbors and friends. She is a rice farmer and hog-grower and earns money by selling harvested rice and fattened pigs. Vuffie works hard to sustain her family and to be able to extend help to her friends also. 

Vuffie is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP from CEVI to purchase fertilizer and pig feed. She hopes to have a stable business and says that receiving this loan would help her immensely.


About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and pig feed

loans.name: Billah

texts.en:
Billah is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water and her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past two years, Billah  has operated a retail shop, selling goods in the local community. Her husband also contributes to the family’s income. Billah’s major business challenge is seasonality. 

Billah decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She is requesting a 40,000 KES loan to purchase sacks of sugar, wheat flour, and maize flour. In the future, Billah hopes to open another retail shop and improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of sugar, wheat flour and maize flour

loans.name: Consolata

texts.en: Consolata S. is a widowed lady with five children between the ages of 22 and 6. Her business is located at Shisejeri market in Kakamega near Eregi College. Kakamega is the western region of Kenya and is well known for its large-scale production of sugarcane and is known as the sugar belt region. She owns a general store in which she sells items such as sugar, salt, cooking fat, blankets, bags, and other items to the local people and the students of Eregi College. She has been in this business for the last 15 years now and has managed to provide employment to three people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 20,000 KES to increase her stock of general items to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to grow her business and, in the future, open a hardware store. She describes herself as focused, energetic, intelligent, and outgoing.

loans.use: To buy sugar, salt, blankets, and bags

loans.name: Banzragch

texts.en:
Banzragch is 33 years old and lives with his mother, wife, and his four children, ages 2 to 15, in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family lives in his mother’s small house, in the outer ger districts of the city. His oldest son and daughter attend school, while his mother is retired and always cares for his youngest son and daughter, ages 2 and 4. His wife is an entrepreneur, and she supports her family by operating her fruit retail stall at Kharhorin, one of Mongolia's largest markets.    

Banzragch has been supporting his family by operating a taxi business for the past two years. In 2009, he started his taxi business using a car that he bought used. So his first car often broke down. During the past two years, he has been able to gradually improve his living conditions and has gained a lot of experience. He is planning to sell his old car and purchase another secondhand car, due to safety regulations for transportation. He is requesting a 3,500,000-MNT loan to purchase the secondhand car. 

His goal is to improve his living conditions by building his own small house, and then he wants a happy life with his family.

loans.use: To purchase the secondhand car

loans.name: Joe Ann

texts.en:
Joe Ann is a married woman who lives in Cadiiz City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two businesses, a cafeteria and a sari-sari (general) store. Her husband, Eugene, who is 53 years old, buys and sells fish to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have no children. Joe Ann joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired after something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Joe Ann has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 11,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 12,000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing 13,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital for their business so that she can continue to save up for future house improvements. Joe Ann is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon--a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a community member who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Leah Kwamboka

texts.en:
Leah M. is a hard working lady, 47 years old and single, and she has one child aged 20 years old of whom she supports.  Leah's main activity is dairy farming and she has been in this type of business for a period of 10 years and her monthly income is Ksh 10,000.  

Leah has borrowed a loan of Kshs. 40,000 from KADET LTD this being her sixth loan after successfully paying back her previous loans. The loan will be used to purchase dairy feeds and also to purchase one dairy cow.  

The anticipated profits will be used to add more dairy cows.  Her dream is to own a big dairy farm and also educate her child.

loans.use: Purchase dairy feeds and purchase one dairy cow

loans.name: Hariet

texts.en:
Hariet is a married woman who lives in Rizal, Palawan. She earns her living by operating two businesses: a rice-milling business and a general store. Her husband, Johnny G., who is 50 years old, works as a rice-mill operator to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have five children who are 11 to 17 years old. Hariet joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired after something better for her family. With the help of her first loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Hariet has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 5,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 12,000 PHP, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her second loan cycle, she is borrowing 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional capital for the rice-mill business so that she can continue to save up for the future and the expansion of her business. Hariet is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon--a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a community member who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund the operation of her rice-milling machine

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
Criselda S. is from the village of Naggasican Santiago City. She is 30 years old. Criselda is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, Criselda owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling street food and frozen food. Criselda has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2010, Criselda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Criselda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. Criselda is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Criselda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en:
Rosalie E. is a married woman who lives in Cadiz, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store, a motorcycle transport business and a farm. 

Her husband, Robert Glenn E., who is 34 years old, works as a driver to earn his living. 

They have two children who are 1 and 6 years old. 

Rosalie joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Rosalie has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 11th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save up for future house repairs. 

Rosalie is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Salina Chepchirchir

texts.en:
Salina Chepchirchir is 47 years old and a single mother of four children ages 26, 15, 13, and 10 years old, all of whom she supports.  She operates a small cereals store whereby she sells maize and has been operting this business for a period of eight years.  

Salina has applied for a loan of Ksh 40,000 from KADET LTD with which she intends to purchase more bags of maize for resale. This is her sixth loan from KADET LTD.  She successfully paid the previous loan well and in good time. The anticipated profits from her sales will be used to increase the volume of stock she sells.

Salina's hopes and dreams is to cater well for her children's education and also own a bigger store of cereals in the future.

loans.use: Purchase cereals for resale

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria  P. is a 56-year-old widow who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  a sari-sari (general) store and a buy-and-sell coconut business. 

She lives in Cauayan , Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her sari-sari store and buy-and-sell coconut businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. 

Gloria is borrowing PHP 17,000 so that she can  purchase more stocks to sell. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gloria  aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the  Dungganon way.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund her business operations

loans.name: Group Abizerana

texts.en:
Emile is 43 years old and married with four children between 2 and 8 years old. Emile is the president of a group loan called "Abizerana." The group is composed of two gentlemen and four ladies. In the photo, he is the third from the left (in the brown overall outfit). 

Emile owns a boutique and sells sugar, rice, bread, cooking oil, etc. He has been in this business for about two years and his boutique is open from 5 AM until 9 PM every day. 

He will use his portion of the loan to purchase more goods like maize flour and drinks on top of what he is selling now. Emile and his group plan to use the profits from their loans for reinvesting in their businesses.

loans.use: To expand his boutique

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome B. is a married woman who lives in Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. 

She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari (general) store and a ready-to-wear clothes business.  

Her husband, Everett, who is 65 years old, works as a retired employee to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. 

They have three children who are 18 to 33 years old. 

Salome joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Salome has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 16th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 14,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for future house improvement. Salome is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
This is Teodora R., 56, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Romeo, a welder, and mother to their two children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their own household while operating their business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Teodora operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Arlene earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Teodora hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she fervently hopes that her business will stabilize and be successful one day. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Soutoura sont toutes mariées dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 34 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenus dans le marché Château de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente d’oignon, de savon de fabrication locale (kabakourouni), de tubercules (pomme de terre et igname) et des fruits (banane, mangue et orange).
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce les membres du groupe ont adhéré Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2 ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
Madame Fatoumata  K. est connue dans le quartier pour sa vente de savon local. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 20 sacs de savon ‘’kabakourouni’’ au grand marché de Ségou avec les forains de Sikasso. La revente se fait en détail au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché Château à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Madame Fatoumata  K. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge la scolarisation de leurs enfants. 
Elle a pour ambition d’augmenter la taille de son petit commerce dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
 NB :   Korotimi C.  est absente de la photo pour cause de décès dans leur famille.
texts.en:
The seven women in the Soutoura group are all married in monogamous families and are on average 34 years old with four children. They all live in the Hamdallaye neighborhood of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali) and got acquainted through ties of marriage, neighborhood and their revenue-generating activities at the Segou Castle Market. 

Group members buy and sell onions, locally-made soap (kabakourouni), tubers (potatoes and yams) and fruit (bananas, mangoes and oranges). In order to increase their working capital group members joined Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second loan cycle.

Ms. Fatoumata Keita is known in the neighborhood as a vendor of local soap. She plans to use her loan to buy 20 bags of kabakourouni soap at the Segou general market from Sikasso fairground vendors. Retail sales are for cash or credit through home delivery, as itinerant vendors or at the Castle Market, to both men and women customers. 

Ms. Fatoumata Keita hopes to achieve with this loan an average monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA to be reinvested in the business and to take care of her children's schooling. Her aim is to increase the size of her small business in partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

Note: Korotimi C. is absent from the picture due to death in her family.

loans.use: Buy local soap (kabakourouni)

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida is a 57-year-old widow who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  poultry and dry goods (fashion earrings). 

She lives in Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her poultry and dry goods (fashion earrings) businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000.

Aida is borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Aida aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.
Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Soutoura sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames avec en moyenne 35 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le quartier Médine de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenus dans le marché Médine de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente de boissons, d’œufs, de savon, de la friperie (yougou-yougou), d’encens, de pagnes wax et de crème à peau. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce les membres du groupe ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  prêt solidaire.
Madame Mamou  Dembélé compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter un colis de friperie au grand marché de Ségou. La revente se fait en détail au comptant et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant et au marché Médine à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Madame Mamou  Dembélé espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge la scolarisation de leurs enfants.
texts.en:
The ten women in the Soutoura group are for the most part married in polygamous families and are on average 35 years old with four children. They all live in the Medine neighborhood of Segou (fourth administrative region of Mali) and got acquainted through neighborhood ties and their revenue-generating activities at the Medine Market of Segou.

Group members buy and sell beverages, eggs, soap, used clothes (yougou-yougou), incense, “wax” pagnes (colorful West-African fabric), and body cream.

In order to increase their working capital group members joined Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first loan cycle.

Ms. Mamou Dembele will use her loan to buy a bale of used clothes at the Segou general market. Retail sales are for cash or credit through home delivery, as itinerant vendors or at the Medine Market, to both men and women customers. 

Ms. Mamou Dembele hopes to achieve with this loan an average monthly profit of 25,000 FCFA to be reinvested in the business and to take care of her children's schooling.

loans.use: Buy used clothes

loans.name: Abass

texts.ar:
عباس في عمر 32 سنة متزوج وله ولد يعمل في بيع الحديد وتصنيعه له في عمله نحو16 سنة يحب عمله ويتقنه جيدا يريد التطور
والتجدد في العمل يسعى الى زيادة تأمين منزل للعائلة ولذلك فهو يريد من خلال طلب قرض له من المجموعة الى شراء قطعة ارض
له في قريته حيث تعيش العائلة وتكون عائلته قريبا من عمله عباس طموح جدا ومتطور في عمله وله زبائن كثر من محيطه 
وجيرانه وهو مقصد للعمل حيث انه يتقن فن الزخرفة في الحديد وصنع الادوات المنزلية
texts.en: Abass, 32, is married with one son. He has been working for 16 years in manufacturing and selling iron rods. Abass is a hard worker who likes to be up-to-date at work. He wants to get a loan from A. Majmoua to buy a plot of land in the village where his family lives. He wants to build a house there so that he and his family can live near his workplace.  He is very ambitious and has many clients from his neighbors and the people who know him.  He is known for his good work. Abass excels in iron handicraft and in making utensils.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land on which to build a house for his family

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya est composé de sept femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 43 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de leurs activités de petit commerce dans le marché Château de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente des pagnes wax, des habits, de la friperie (communément appelée en Bambara : yougou-yougou), d’encens et du savon. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce et de se ravitailler au comptant, les membres du groupe ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 5ème prêt solidaire. Tous les quatre prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Madame Ramata D. a une grande réputation dans la vente d’encens à Hamdallaye surtout auprès des jeunes mariées. Elle  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 2 kg de Magnonkissèni, 10 bouteilles d’eau de Cologne et une dizaine de tube de parfums de qualité. Elle se ravitaille en ces produits au grand marché de Ségou en gros.
Pour faire de l’encens, elle imbibe le Magnonkissèni dans l’eau de Cologne pendant une semaine au moins ensuite elle l’assaisonne avec du parfum. L’encens ainsi obtenu est réparti enfin entre les bouteilles pour être vendu.  
La revente se fait en détail au comptant et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant et au marché Château à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes. 
Madame Ramata  D. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 45 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité,  prendre en charge les besoins du foyer et la scolarisation des enfants. 
NB : Hinda Koné a accouché raison pour laquelle elle ne figure pas sur la photo
texts.en:
The Danaya group is made up of seven married woman, generally from monogamous families and with an average age 43 and five children each. They all live in the Hamdallaye neighborhood of the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali). They became acquainted through kinship and through their sales activities at the Château de Ségou market.

The group members buy and sell “pagnes wax” (colorful West African fabrics), clothing, used clothing (commonly called "yougou-yougou" in the Bambara language), incense, and soap. In order to increase their working capital and pay cash for supplies, the group members joined Soro Yiriwaso and are on their fifth group loan. The four previous loans are fully repaid.

Mrs. Ramata D. has a good reputation as an incense merchant in Hamdallaye, especially with young married women. She plans to use her loan to buy two kilograms of "Magnonkissèni" (seeds of a wild plant), ten bottles of cologne, and ten tubes of quality fragrances. She buys these items wholesale at the big market in Ségou. To make incense, she soaks Magnonkissèni in cologne for at least a week, then adds fragrance. The resulting incense is put in bottles to be sold retail for cash and credit. She sells from her home, as an ambulant vendor, and at the Château market, primarily to women.

With this loan Mrs. Ramata D. hopes to make an average monthly profit of 45,000 CFA, which will be reinvested in the business and used for household expenses and school fees.

Note:  Hinda Koné is not pictured because she was in labor.

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials to make incense

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Benkadi sont mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec un âge moyen de 37 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Médine de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenus dans le marché Médine de Ségou. 
Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de savon,  de charbon de bois, de mèche à cheveux, de pâtes alimentaires et  des fruits du jujubier. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 1er prêt solidaire.
Madame Korotoumou C. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter dix cartons de savons. Elle se ravitaille en savon au grand marché de Ségou en gros et effectue sa vente en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à domicile, en ambulant et au marché Médine à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Madame Korotoumou  C. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et prendre en charge les petits besoins du foyer. 
Elle a pour ambition, à l’image des autres membres du groupe d’augmenter le volume de leurs activités dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en: The six women in the Benkadi group are married and on average are 37 years old with 4 children.  Most  of them live in monogamous families. They all live in the Medine district of Ségou (fourth administrative region of Mali) and became acquainted through neighborhood ties and their businesses in Segou's Medine market. The group members have small businesses selling soap, charcoal, hair extensions, pasta and jujube fruit.  In order to increase their working capital, the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso  loan program where  they have their first solidarity loan.  Mrs. Korotoumou C. plans to use her loan to buy ten boxes of soap. She stocks up on soap wholesale at the Segou Grand Market and sells her merchandise retail, for cash and on credit, at home, door-to-door and at the Médine market to a clientele composed of men and women.  With this loan, she hopes to make an average monthly profit of 25,000 CFA which will used to reinvest in the business and to take care of small household expenses.  Her goal and that of the other group members is to increase their sales volume in this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso.

loans.use: To buy soap

loans.name: Dorci

texts.en:
Dorci is a 31-year-old seamstress. She is married to Hengky and has been blessed with three children, namely: Faldi, 8, who is in the second grade of Primary school; Firman, 6, who is in kindergarten and Rafi, 4. Dorci lives with her family in Oebufu Village.

Dorci has been doing her job as a seamstress for three years. The income generated from her business is unstable. There are certain moments when Dorci has many orders, but there are also moments when there are few orders. The beginning of the school year is the high season for Dorci when she can receive orders for up to 10 clothes in a month. But in normal days she only receives 2-4 orders a month. Dorci takes 2-3 days to complete one clothing order. The profit generated from her business is spent on the everyday needs of her family as well as her children's school fees. Dorci realizes the need to improve her income to enable her to provide a better life for her family.

Therefore, she started to think about other businesses besides sewing in order to increase her income. She wants to buy piglets and chickens to raise. Therefore, Dorci is requesting loan amounting to IDR 3,000,000 to buy piglets and chickens. She hopes that the loan can help her improve her business.

loans.use: To buy piglets and chickens to raise

loans.name: Rushambya Twimukye Tukore Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
T. Lazarus is the leader of Rushambya Twimukye Tukore group in Kihihi. He is 44 years old and married with four children with two in school. 

Lazarus is involved in the farming business; he grows matooke and he has a tea leaves plantation. Lazarus is lucky that there is a tea factory in his locality of Rushambya and he is able to make 120,000/= as weekly profits. He has been in business for seven years, and his determination has made him succeed. 

His dream is to have a happy and educated family in addition to an expanded business.

loans.use: Expansion of the farm by buying more land for agriculture.

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto is a 34-year-old man who is married to Martha, 33. Roberto is a father of two daughters: Sandra, who is 10 years old and in the fourth grade of elementary school, and Avira, who is 6 years old. Roberto and family live in a modest house in Tuapukan Village. They are migrants from East Timor. Roberto sells fish door to door, but the income from the business is not enough for him to support his family. In order to get rice for his family, Roberto sometimes has to work as hired worker in the rice field. 

Roberto has been running his fish selling business since 2008 using his own business capital but his business has not improved yet. In his family, Roberto is the only person who generates income. Roberto dreams to improve his business to enable him to provide a better life for his family. Roberto is requesting a loan from TLM amounting to IDR 4,000,000. He plans to spend the loan to buy more fish. Roberto hopes the loan will help his business and family’s lives.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Sarlince

texts.en:
Sarlince is a-38-year-old lady who works as a tailor. Sarlince is married to Ricky and has six children. They are: Rizal, who is in the third grade of a Senior high school; Sari, who is in the second grade of Senior high school; Yosua, who is in the second grade of Junior high school; Sella, who is in the first grade of Junior high school; Nickyds, 4 years old; and Lili, 8 months. Sarlince and her family live in the middle of town, exactly in the village of Naikolan. 
Sarlince is a persistent woman who is always looking for opportunities to expand her business in the field of sewing. She has been running this business for almost four years. 

Sarlince always tries to make innovations in sewing by creating her own models. Although her business is categorized as a small business and can only generate a small income, Sarlince dreams of improving her business to become bigger. 

Currently, Sarlince is using one sewing machine to fill her customer orders. Sometimes Sarlince receives many orders at a time. She would love to complete all of her customer orders on time with satisfactory quality.  

Therefore Sarlince hopes she can buy a new sewing machine. The new machine will be used to create button holes and to do other specific work. To make her dream come true, Sarlince is requesting a loan of IDR 4,000,000 from TLM. Sarlince believes that the loan will be a good support for her to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more seeds and pigs

loans.name: Amani Kwetu Group

texts.fr: Nabutote B. N.  est entrepreneur, leader du groupe d’affaire Amani kwetu, âgée de 43 ans, femme vivant seule, mère de 2 enfants. Ses fils ainé et cadette sont respectivement âgés de 23 ans et 20 ans. La cliente  Nabutote B. N.  est  vendeuse des boissons (Primus, Fanta, Coca). Elle vend ses produits  à son domicile. Elle démarra son activité avec un fonds de 30$, fonds propre issu de son salaire, quand elle travaillait comme une domestique dans une famille (dans la ville de Bukavu-Sud Kivu). Il ya 9 ans qu’elle est en activité. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouvelles marchandises (10 casiers de bières Primus, 3 casiers de Metzinger, 10 casiers de Fanta sucré et Coca.).  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise, construire une buvette, acheter un moyens de transport pour ses marchandises dans le long terme, scolariser ses enfants et passer le reste de sa vie en paix. La cliente Nabutote B. N.  remercie Hekima pour  ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe Amani Kwetu est constitué de 23 membres. Cependant, la cliente Baeni B. n'est pas visible sur la photo du groupe.
texts.en: Nabutote B. N. is a businesswoman and heads the Amani Kwetu business group. She is 43 years old, lives alone, and is the mother of two children. Her sons are 23 and 20 years old. Nabutote B. N. sells drinks (Primus beer, Fanta, Coca-Cola). She sells her goods at home. She started up her business with a fund of $30, which came out of her own salary when she worked as a domestic for a family (in the city of Bukavu-South Kivu). She has run her business for 9 years. This new loan should serve to supply her with new merchandise (10 cases of Primus beer, 10 cases of Metzinger, 10 cases of sweetened Fanta and Coca-Cola). In addition, she aims to enlarge her enterprise, build a refreshment bar, buy means of transportation for her goods in the long run, educate her children, and spend the rest of her life in peace. Nabutote Bore N. thanks Hekima (one of Kiva's field partners) for its work dedicated to poor women who are excluded from the classical banking system. The Amani Kwetu group is made up of 23 members. However, one member, Baeni B., is not visible in the group photo.

loans.use: 10 cases of Primus beer, 3 cases of Metzinger, and 10 cases of sweetened Fanta and Coca-Cola.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana is a 36-year-old lady. She is married to Lambertus a 40 year old mason. Susana and her husband have been blessed with 3 children, namely Marni, 16 years old who is in the first grade of Senior high school; Novi, 12 years old who is in the sixth grade of elementary school; and Marten, 9 years old in the third grade of Elementary school. Susana and her family live in Liliba village.

As a mason, Lambertus earns only a small income for the family. Therefore, Susana decided to find another way to help her husband in order to provide a better life for her family. She works selling various products. She walks from house to house offering the products. Susana has been doing this job for 5 years. Her income depends on the number of products sold. She is not quite satisfied of her current sales arrangement and tried to find a way to sell her own products rather than selling the products of others. But this is very difficult for Susana to make this come true as she needs a larger working capital.

To realize her dream, Susana is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 3,000,000 from TLM to purchase goods to sell. She hopes that the loan will help her improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase goods to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy vegetables and cooking spices to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more agricultural products to sell

loans.name: Nova

texts.en:
Nova is a 27-year-old single woman who graduated from a vocational school. She lives with her parents in a remote village of Naikliu. It is situated about 85 km from Kupang. Nova has 6 siblings. She is very interested in running a beauty salon and according to her, there are no other people running this type of business in the village. 

Using her own capital, Nova opened a beauty salon business in the village of Naibonat. Her business place is located nearby the main road. She believes that her business place is a strategic place that provides her the best opportunity to run the business. According to Nova, her business is still small and very simple. Currently, she only has limited equipment to run the business. With this limitation, the profit generated is still small. Besides that, she still has to pay for the rental fee of IDR 2,500,000 per year. Nova expects to soon have more and better equipment so that she can improve her business. To do so, Nova needs additional capital. 

She is requesting a loan of IDR 5,000,000 from TLM. She plans to use the loan to buy new equipment and other beauty products to support her salon. She hopes that the loan will help her improve her business.

loans.use: To buy new equipment and other beauty products

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a 35-year-old man who lives in the village of Haukoto - Fatukoa, Maulafa, situated about 20 km from Kupang City. Daniel is married and has two children: Meisjen, 8 years old and in first grade, and Dorcas, 4 years old. Daniel has been running a small kiosk business for more than 3 years, and he is assisted by his wife in managing the kiosk. He initiated his business using his own very small amount of capital. He sells shampoo, cigarettes, sugar, coffee, snacks for children and other items in his kiosk. Daniel can generate a daily profit of IDR 15,000 - 25,000. He uses the profit to support his family, but the profit only enables him to buy their basic necessities.

To increase his income, Daniel tried to engage in cattle selling and buying, but the income is still unstable as it depends on the number of cattle sold. Daniel really wants to improve his business and generate more income from it, but he does not have the capital to do so. Therefore, Daniel is requesting a loan of IDR 10,000,000 from TLM. He plans to enlarge his kiosk business by adding other commodities and also to buy 2 calves for breeding. Daniel really hopes that TLM will provide him with the loan to improve his businesses.

loans.use: to buy more products for his store and calves for breeding

loans.name: Yakobus

texts.en:
Yakobus is a 26-year-old fishmonger. He lives in Labat, a village which is situated about 3 km from the city of Kupang. Yakobus lives with his wife, Maria, and with his two sons, Feri, 5 years old, and Oktovianus, 2 1/2 years old. His house is very simply constructed with a zinc roof, cement floor and palm-branched walls. Yakobus has been running his business for almost 5 years. He works from 6 a.m. until the fish are all sold, about 3 p.m. Yakobus can generate a daily profit of IDR 30,000 - IDR 50,000, which he uses to provide rice, vegetables and side dishes for his family. His income obviously depends on the amount of fish sold. Yakobus realizes that the profit is still not comparable with his family's everyday needs.

Yakobus experienced difficulty when his second child was sick and he did not have money to pay the doctor and medicines, so he had to borrow from his neighbors. Because of this situation, Yakobus wants to improve his business, but needs additional capital. Yakobus heard about TLM from the field officer who came to the market. He then became interested in joining the individual lending program. Yakobus is requesting a loan of IDR 5,000,000. He plans to buy large quantities of fish, such as belang kuning (yellow mottled), to sell in order to generate more profit. He assures that he will be able to save some of his profit for his children’s schooling and health care. Yakobus really hopes that TLM will provide him with the loan.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to move his business and to add more inventory

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina, 58 years old, is the mother of 3 children: Sarce, Diana and Henesti. Both Sarce and Diana graduated only from junior high school. To meet her family's needs, Paulina sells various vegetables. She has a vegetable farmland; although it is not too large, her family very much relies on it. Paulina plants her farm with various vegetables such as mustard greens, water spinach, sweet potatoes and eggplant and sells the vegetables door-to-door. She is also assisted by her daughters in selling vegetables at home.

If her farm doesn't produce enough vegetables, then Paulina will buy additional vegetables from other farmers at Inpres Market (a traditional market in Kupang) and resell them. Paulina can generate daily profits of IDR 10,000 -20,000, which she uses to buy basic necessities for her family. Paulina's income is unstable and sometimes it is very small compared to the cost of daily necessities. Paulina wants to buy more vegetables to sell in order to increase her income, but she doesn't have enough money to do so.

Paulina heard that TLM offers a lending program for poor entrepreneurs like her. She is very interested in joining the program and is requesting a loan of IDR 3,000,000 from TLM. She really hopes to get the loan so she will be able to increase her income by selling more vegetables.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Raed

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 34 years old, married and has 2 children. 

Raed has a long experience in car maintenance business. In 2002 he opened his own car maintenance workshop and started working in his local area. Now, he is being well known and has an excellent reputation.

He is requesting $2400 loan to install a new ceiling for the store. He is aiming to develop his business so he would be able to improve his family life style.

loans.use: Install a new ceiling for the store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Rent new shop and purchase new goods

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 36 years old, married and lives with one parent.

In 2005, Haidar decided to open his own business to improve his life standards. Therefore he opened women’s accessories and cosmetics shop, in addition to a small part for women clothes. He is being well known in his local area and has an excellent reputation.

He is requesting $3000 loan to renovate his shop and install shutters. He aiming to grow bigger and open a second branch in the future.

loans.use: To renovate the shop and install shutters

loans.name: Kashebeya K Tukorerehamwe Grp Group

texts.en: B. Yeusi is the leader of the Kashebeya K Tukorerehamwe Grp. He is 46 years old and married, with 5 children all older than 8 years and in school. B. Yeusi is a farmer who grows and sells tea and tea leaves to the Kayonza Tea factory. He has been in business for 10 years and has been successful because there is a ready market of the factory and consumers. As a result, he makes a weekly profit of 100,000 UGX. B. Yeusi is a very hardworking and focused man whose dream is to expand his tea farm and his banana plantation and to have a happy family.

loans.use: to expand his tea farm

loans.name: Bisoboka Women's Group-Lugazi

texts.en: Margret N. is 45 years old and has been a farmer for 20 years. The land she farms is located in the town of Kizigo in Lugazi. She attributes her longevity in this field to her commitment to hard work. In the future, she would like to open a retail shop. She is single, has four children, and is a member of the Bisoboka Women's Group. She plans to use her portion of this loan to buy high-grade fertilizer for her farm.

loans.use: The purchase of high-grade manure for her farms

loans.name: Safaa

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 33 years old, married and has two children. In 2007, Safaa opened his own food market in an area where the competition is minimal. He is well known in his community and has an excellent reputation.

Safaa is requesting a $3000 loan to install new windows for the shop and put a sign at the entrance. He is aiming to extend his business and improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To install new windows for the shop and put a sign at the entrance

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.ar:
محمد في عمر 51 سنة متزوج وله 3 اولاد يعمل في تصليح وبيع الادوات الصحية له في عمله 30 سنة يعمل بجد ونشاط وحيوية
يريد التطور في مهنته وزيادة مدخوله وتطوير عائلته من الناحية المادية والمعنوية يريد من خلال مصلحته الى زيادة المدخول
يسعى جاهدا الى عدم الاحتياج فهو يعاني من منافسة في محيطه العملي يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى شراء عدة كاملة للمصلحة وتوسيع العمل حتى يشمل ورش كبيرة طموح مثابر ويلقى الدعم الكامل من عائلته ومحيطه
texts.en: Mohamed is 25 years old and married with three children. He works in the repair and selling of health/sanitation appliances and has 30 years experience in this field. He's energetic and enthusiastic and wants to develop his skills and increase his income. He wishes to help his family both materially and otherwise. With his loan request he wants to become more independent, as he faces competition in the market from his local area. He also hopes to purchase goods, expand his work to include workshops. He's very ambitious and has full support from his family and all those around him.

loans.use: Purchase tools for the full benefit of his family.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.ar: محمد في عمر 45 سنة متزوج وله 5 اولاد يعمل في الديكورات وتحسين المنازل له في عمله 30 سنة يحب عمله ويريد من خلال مصلحته تطويرها وجعلها اكثر تقدم وتجدد يحب عائلته وهي كل اهتمامه وعائلته تعطيه كل الاهتمام له زبائن من محيطه دائما يتعرض للمنافسة بسبب كثرة المصلحة لكنه متميز في عمله حيث انه يواكب التطور يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى تطوير مصلحته من خلال شراء سقالات + دعائم حديد
texts.en: Muhammad is 45 years old and married with 5 children. He works in interior design and house renovation, and has 30 years of experience. He loves his work and with this loan he wants to develop, advance and rejuvenate his business. He loves his family and they are his sole priority, just as he is theirs. He has many locA. customers. He's in a constantly competitive market, but stands out as he tries to be constantly up to date. With his loan he hopes to develop by purchasing new scaffolding and iron supports.

loans.use: Buy iron pillars and scaffolding

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy food items and utensils to sell to her customers

loans.name: Ali

texts.ar: علي متزوج وله ول له من العمر 44 سنة يعمل سائق نقل عام له في عمله 8 سنوات يحب عائلته وهي كل اهتمامه يسعى جاهدا الى تأمين العيش الكريم له ولعائلته يريد التطور فهو يمتلك سيارة خاصة له لكنه يريد تجديدها حتى يستطيع ان يستقبل اكبر عدد من الزبائن خاصة ان مصلحته تريد دائما التطور ليستطيع استقبال السواح ونقلهم في المناطق السياحية لذلك فهو يريد من خلال طلب قرض له من المجموعة الى صيانة سيارته
texts.en: Ali is 44 years old and married with a son. He works as a taxi driver and has 8 years experience. He loves his family very much, they are his top priority and he wants to secure a comfortable standard of living for them. He wants the loan because though he owns his own car, he would like to renovate it so that he can increase his number of customers. He would particularly like to work in transporting tourists between tourist sites, and so with the loan from al-Majmoua he would like to perform maintenance on his car.

loans.use: Car Maintenance

loans.name: Mutai Development Association-Jinja Group

texts.en: M. Sulaiman is 50 years old and a member of the Mutai Development Association-Jinja. For the last six years, he has made a living by selling  charcoal, firewood and milk to people in his town. He began by selling charcoal only, but gradually expanded his product offerings. He is diligent, focused and hard-working, and exudes confidence when you meet him for the first time. His businesses generate an income of 200,000 shillings a month, and with 10 children to support, he plans to use his portion of this group loan to buy more charcoal and firewood to sell to his customers.

loans.use: To buy charcoal and firewood to sell to his customers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kancerere  Tutungukye Group, Kihihi

texts.en: Owen T. leads the Kancerere Tutungukye Loan Group--Kihihi. He is 24 years old, married and has for the last five years made a living running a retail shop in Omukengoma's trading centre. He works with his wife, and as a team they earn about 100,000 UGX a week in profit. Owen also runs a side business buying and selling coffee, and earned enough money here to open the retail shop where he now sells sugar, salt, cooking oil, soap and and other items. His goal is to expand his retail business and buy land he can use to begin farming.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell from a store

loans.name: Moussa

texts.ar: موسى في عمر 53 سنة متزوج وله 5 اولاد يعمل في بيع الزيوت وتجارة الزيوت للسيارات له في عمله 8 سنوات يحب عمله ويتطور فيه دائما يريد دائما تأمين العيش الجيد والكريم له ولعائلته له تاريخ جيد مع المجموعة وقد ساهم في زيادة مدخوله وكان يلقى الدعم الكامل من عائلته يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى شراء بضاعة جديدة
texts.en: Moussa is 53 years old and married with 5 children. He works in providing gas and oil for cars. He has 8 years experience. He loves what he does, and wants to develop it. He wantes to secure a comfortable standard of living for himself and his family. He has a good credit history with al-Majmoua, which has contributed to an increase in his income. He has the full support of his family and through this loan he wants to purchase new goods.

loans.use: Buy products for sale

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano is married, has five children and makes a living by running a store in the town of Kurgantyube. Her main products are food items, tea, coffee, sweets and refrigerated beverages. She has been in this line of work for six years and is applying for this loan, for $3,000, to buy fresh groceries, which always sell well in winter. She wants to expand her store so that she can provide a better life for her family.
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being the home of a key post along the Silk Road and the place where the rule of Alexander the Great ended. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 percent of the country is mountainous and only seven percent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients have viable business propositions. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell in a retail store

loans.name: Firdavs

texts.en:
Firdavs B. lives in Kurgantyube, Tajikistan, where he is a successful businessman who has been selling a variety of eyeglasses over the past four years. A husband and father, he provides the family's only income. 

He has one vending location in the market where he sells his goods, and he wishes to expand his business by renting a second vending location. For this purpose he is requesting a loan of $1,500. This loan will increase his business sales, allowing Firdavs to diversify his merchandise and better provide for his family.

loans.use: To buy new goods for selling

loans.name: Hasan

texts.ar:
حسن في عمر 23 سنة غير متزوج يعمل في دهان موبيليا للمنازل له في عمله 10 سنوات يحب عمله ويطمح بأن يصبح صاحب كاليري خاص به
يحب ان يكون عائلة وان يطور من عمله فهو طموح محب للعمل ملتزم مجد ونشيط له زبائن كثر من محيطه واقاربه واصدقائه يلقى الدعم الكامل من عائلته يريد من خلال طلب قرض له من المجموعة الى زيادة البضائع في العمل لدعم المصلحة فهو يلقى منافسة كبيرة من محيطه ولكن ما ينقصه هو المادة لدعم عمله
texts.en: Hasan is 23 years old and single. He has been working for the past 10 years as a home furniture refinisher. He very much enjoys his work and aspires to one day own his own gallery. He brings to bear great industriousness and energy to his work, which he is always seeking to further improve. Hasan enjoys the patronage of his friends and relatives as well as other locals. Because of the stiff competition he faces, Hasan was interested in seeking a loan from Al Majmoua to procure more materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for business

loans.name: Zafar

texts.en:
Zafar B. is 29 years old. He has had a trying life but he keeps an optimistic outlook. He remains a strong and persevering person, intent on improving his family’s standard of living. Zafar sells petrol and diesel fuel. Over three years of selling fuel, he already has got enough experience to do his work successfully and has clients who always come to him. 

Today Zafar is requesting a loan of 7,500 TJS that will be used for increasing his inventory and meet his clients' demands. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of Zafar’s business, and they will sincerely thank you.
